ping @mistercrunch

Hello, I experience the same behavior connecting the tool to an Impala table.
The only workaround that I found is to create a new column with the expression:
CASE my_bool_column WHEN true THEN 'True' ELSE 'False' END

@ZamoraAndres check out #3007 please and whether the Boolean representation in Impala is false/true (and not 0/1 like in SQLite) just like in Postgres. In this case we should just add Impala to the list of affected DBs over there.

@kkalyan I believe this change is a side effect of the caching restructure (cc @mistercrunch) however one could argue showing â€˜No dataâ€™ is more accurate than failing gracefully as users could misinterpret the results as they would be unaware that the filters werenâ€™t functioning.

Note weâ€™re working on a dashboard redesign which includes a better UX this type of situation.
lgtm
lgtm

@michellethomas upon further investigation this regression doesn't seem to be related to the auto-escape feature but rather [this](https://github.com/zzzeek/sqlalchemy/commit/2392ae1900f112c44ed966783d1dedfb88f13353)  SQLAlchemy commit (released in version `1.2.0`) which escapes percent signs (`%`) for all dialects where the param style is either `format` or `pyformat` per [this](https://github.com/zzzeek/sqlalchemy/blob/e3323df4bd781a593e90c1cb4a187ff37cc04e5a/lib/sqlalchemy/sql/compiler.py#L2999) statement which is [true](https://github.com/dropbox/PyHive/blob/19d7c2b8fb8b19dadeb2339d4d3f42c8f09204c1/pyhive/presto.py#L31) for Presto. Hence by upgrading SQLAlchemy from `1.1.9` to `1.2.2` ([PR](https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/4299)) the percent signs were doubly escaped in Presto per the `PrestoEngineSpec` causing the regression.

Information gathered from user:

* schedule interval / cron statement
* dependencies (partitioned tables we should wait for, if any, other scheduled queries)
* scheduled until (we not allow users to set that too far in the future, forcing them to push a button to re-schedule their query, trying to prevent abuse / accumulation of useless compute)
* ...
